column4: in what file can I review the messages I get during the bootime ?
dmesg
some messages aren't there.. is there any other place I can look for ?
try forming a more complete question and include what version of ubuntu you are using
grep for EE or ee ?
dmesg|grep ee ?
it might just be seeing a floppy drive and not be of any real importance
it's gives a table of some values (I don't have enough time to read it at it continues to boot) and then /dev/sda2 mounted or something, so I think it's related to my filesystem
I thought you could hit pause..
didn't work, I pressed pause many times it still booted without stopping
Still kinda fuzzy in the am here
umount before you try and mount
"dmesg|grep clean" didn't report a "/dev/sda1 clean..."  and that message is appears when I boot so seems dmesg does not have all logged or something
fsck it manually

I found when it was comming from, I have /dev/sda4 10gb vfat with XP on it, when I do fsck.vfat /dev/sda4 it says it has differences in boot sector and it can restore it from original or backup the current one, any idea what should I do ?
scarry..  if the current one does not work you can try the backup, but may I suggest you backup your partition info first

Backing up the mbr... Go to Terminal.. cd Desktop .... sudo dd if=/dev/sda of=mbr.backup bs=512 count=1   Note: 512 includes all partition info.. Use 446 To exclude partition info... To include the first partition (16 bytes) use 462... Second Partition 478... Third 478... Use hda if needed on your system... copy mbr.backup to a USB Drive (or any media acessible from livecd)
if I check the XP and it's ok, may I just decide "backup original" option in order to get rid of that message at boot. Because as far as I know currently everything works fine.
did you see my post on backing up mbr
yep, doing it now
Restoring the mbr...Insert usb drive...Boot livecd... Copy the mbr.backup from usb to the Desktop...go to Terminal...cd Desktop ... then... dd if=mbr.backup of=/dev/sda bs=1
thank you for help, going to check if my XP is still booting, bye. Thanks again.
